;Talia Chetrit 希望您知道她的伴侣 Denis 不'通常，他们不会戴着古驰束缚带用奶瓶喂养儿子。尽管如此，她还是理解这种困惑。 Chetrit 是一位摄影师，她经常以自己和家人作为作品的主题，这似乎将她置于日记艺术家的血统中，例如 ;莎莉·曼;和;埃莉诺·卡鲁奇;。但最近，当我参观她位于纽约州北部的工作室时，她告诉我，她认为她的所有作品“纯属虚构”。

;
;
;
;

;Chetrit 在美国的首次个展目前正在康涅狄格州哈特福德的沃兹沃斯雅典娜博物馆展出，其乍一看似乎是四处漂泊的摄影生涯除了她的自画像和家人的照片外，她还拍摄了喜怒无常的长焦街头照片、光学上棘手的静物画和巧妙的时尚照片。她甚至还潜入了令人陶醉的概念领域，展示了她在高中时拍摄的照片，回想起来这些照片具有深刻的意义。然而，归根结底，她不同的作品是一个统一追求的一部分，旨在区分和玩弄摄影惯例，并由此扩展，在我们对图像可以揭示或隐藏什么的期望中找出漏洞。

;;;;

;Chetrit 在华盛顿特区出生并长大，她回忆道，她“从子宫里出来就称自己为艺术家”。她十几岁时就开始拍照，在父母的洗衣房里设立了一间暗室，并在高中时接管了一个保管室。但她以典型的难以捉摸的方式声称，她“对别人的摄影从来不感兴趣”。直到后来，在芝加哥艺术学院学习期间，她才得出结论：她的想法更适合这种媒介。她在高中时拍摄的、后来重新调整用途的照片绝不是艺术大师的作品。在很大程度上，它们正是您所期望的。其中有一幅穿着网球短裙、撅起嘴的自画像，散发着孩子气的任性和萌芽的性意识。在她为朋友拍摄的照片中，有些拍摄对象实际上表现出青春期的尴尬，而另一些拍摄对象则戏剧性地表现出他们的焦虑。两位女性朋友的裸体肖像在不适和不为人知的性感之间取得了微妙的平衡。现在看来，这部早期作品的力量和魅力直接源于其朴实无华。其他摄影师也试图直接捕捉少女时代的本质——例如，曼在她令人惊叹的、有争议的系列“直系亲属”中，或者贾斯汀·库兰在她更具寓言性的电影“;女孩照片;。”但切特里特新颖的自我挪用行为通过她年轻时的自我笨拙的尝试来掩盖真相，从而传达了真相。

;;;;

;当时的另一组图像预示了切特里特对摄影小说的兴趣。在其中，她的朋友们装死，是虚构的谋杀案的受害者，看起来既可怕又不令人信服。 （其中一张照片中，一名受害者倒在门上，她血淋淋的手放在一张纸上，以免弄脏地板。）这些照片让我想起;Weegee; 耸人听闻的犯罪现场照片，以及我们文化对真实犯罪的残忍痴迷。我想起校园枪击事件的恐怖，以及从未出现在公众视野中的后果照片。我想到了在战争中丧生的儿童的图像，这些图像被推送到我们的社交媒体上。然而，对于十几岁的切特里特来说，构建的场景主要是一种制作不无聊的图片的方式。她告诉我，“我在高中时经历了一个突破性的时刻，当时我想，‘哦，我不需要等到我的生活变得有趣。’” ”

;;;;

;Chetrit 从未放弃这样的想法：摄影可以用来在我们单调的日常生活之外创造一个虚幻的世界。在她成熟的照片中，她似乎在挑战你相信她说的是实话。其中一些照片，比如在切特里特沃兹沃斯 (Wadsworth of Chetrit) 展出的一幅照片，她在生下儿子后立即将儿子抱在胸前，明显带有亲密的味道。这些正是您所期望的摄影师所拥有的，他致力于拉近观众的距离并变得“真实”。但其他的，比如她一系列面无表情的“无底线”自画像，她在镜头前赤裸着腰部以下，或者是她和丹尼斯在田园风光中做爱的两张轻松的照片，这些照片被相机的释放线蜿蜒的黑色线条，感觉更像是一种亲密的滑稽表演。切特里特似乎在嘲笑我们对自我暴露的渴望，但实际上却没有透露太多。她告诉我，在她和丹尼斯开始约会后不久，她就开始制作自己的性爱照片，作为一种“测试”，看看他是否“愿意参与我的工作”。她继续说道，“那不是我们的性生活。这就是我们与相机的性生活，以及相机对我们的性生活和当时的关系的影响。”

;;;;

;Chetrit 的编辑工作让她能够尝试设计服装，比如她从各个公司借来的 Gucci 背带。造型师朋友和合作者。她显然很高兴为丹尼斯穿上一系列高端女装和前卫的、受束缚启发的套装，以及将她还在襁褓中的儿子的双腿与一双光亮的长及大腿的细高跟靴并置，这具有挑衅性的陌生感。 。为了拍摄一系列照片，她邀请了化妆师兼安迪·沃霍尔 (Andy Warhol) 的合伙人科里·蒂平 (Corey Tippin) 为她设计了他标志性的小丑风格。在一张照片中，切特里特的脸上挂着一只长袜，就像瓷娃娃和银行劫匪的不正当混搭。你会感觉到她对拍摄照片的看法就像孩子对玩装扮的看法一样：将其视为拓展可能性界限的机会。

;即使 Chetrit 认为她的作品“纯属虚构”，但她的图像有时会暴露出纪录片导演的眼光。照片中，她的儿子可爱地在丹尼斯的胸前挥舞，一只脚踩在父亲满是胡茬的下巴上，这是一幅激动人心、真实的家庭生活写照。在她为丹尼斯拍摄的照片中，无论多么荒唐或做作，都无法掩盖他是她自愿的、常常是快乐的同谋。 （她告诉我，他对她更奇怪的要求的反应总是：“什么？不！好吧”）同样，她父母的照片流露出他们支持的游戏精神，并感人地暴露了他们对彼此的感情。她的自画像故意偏离自我物化，有一种偷偷摸摸的反抗气氛，就像她怀孕时拍的那张自画像，赤身裸体，跨坐在镜子上，相机贴在眼睛上。切特里特的摄影要求我们反思图像创造的想象世界。但有时，即使通过游乐场的镜头，也可以瞥见一些小真理，例如爱或自爱。

;自 10 月 7 日哈马斯袭击以色列以来，以色列随后对加沙的轰炸和入侵，反犹太主义事件已;

;

;;我们谈话的背景是10月7日发生的事情，以及以色列对此的反应。从基本的因果关系来看，如果没有对加沙的轰炸，其中一些事件就不会发生。话虽这么说，我不想通过追根溯源来为犯下仇恨犯罪的人开脱。 9/11 之后，美国有很多人对穆斯林犯下仇恨犯罪，但我不想因为威斯康星州有人烧毁一座清真寺而责怪奥萨马·本·拉登。;

;

;没有人强迫任何人做出反犹太主义的行为。理解人们行为的环境以及导致他们以特定方式行为的环境与为仇恨犯罪开脱之间是有区别的，我只想在那里划清界限。我确实认为，当前辩论中的问题之一，无论是针对以色列境外的仇恨犯罪，还是针对 10 月 7 日发生的事件，一些寻求解释的人随后被指控纵容。当然，这就是发生在联合国秘书长身上的事情，他谴责哈马斯的行为，但表示这些行为并非凭空产生。因此，试图谈论因果关系和为某项行动辩解是有区别的。

;

;;哈马斯是在以色列和巴勒斯坦之间长期冲突的政治背景下产生的。哈马斯肯定有其背景，即使我们对他们的行为方式感到震惊。我不知道有人在伦敦对英国犹太人大喊大叫诽谤的背景是什么。;

;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;

;我认为我们在这里讨论的问题是以色列和巴勒斯坦发生的事件如何影响和分裂以色列和巴勒斯坦以外的人们。显然，正如您所知，英国和其他地方的犹太人在这一问题上并没有统一的声音，但自 10 月 7 日以来，主流犹太机构一直坚定地支持以色列的行动和政策。因此，散居海外的主流犹太人有一种方式认同以色列，然后又被其他人认同以色列，我认为这只是为犹太建筑受到攻击提供了一个背景。

;
;
;

;刚刚发生了一件可怕的事情，那就是“加沙”一词在维纳大屠杀图书馆外被涂上了红色油漆，该图书馆是一个致力于研究大屠杀的图书馆和档案馆。这绝不是一项合法行为，但显然，无论执行该行为的人是谁，都将这座建筑认定为与犹太人有关的建筑，并且他将犹太人与对以色列国的支持联系起来。如果你愿意的话，这是我作为一名学者的发言。在这种情况下，在我看来，我们要么放弃，要么尝试理解为什么人们会这样做。否则，人文学科就没有真正发挥作用。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;我只是不确定犯下仇恨犯罪的人类型是否真的关心主流犹太组织是否支持与以色列同在。我觉得仇恨犯罪可能是独立于这种背景而发生的，那可能是两列在平行轨道上运行的火车，但它们实际上并没有连接。;

;

;是的。

;< p >;;特别是对于反犹太主义或任何形式的偏执，我确实想知道查看直接原因是否会遗漏一些东西。;

;
;
;

;是的。从某种意义上说，你的问题的答案是我们不知道。但是，在某些方面，我认为情况可能与你所说的相反。在正常情况下，会发生很多类似于流氓行为的仇恨犯罪。有人在街上看到一个明显是犹太人的人，他们就会对他们挑剔。这是众所周知的现象。但是，如果你看看我刚才举的例子，有人在专门纪念大屠杀的图书馆和档案馆的墙上涂抹“加沙”，例如，如果你看到人们向犹太教堂投掷燃烧弹，那么我认为有人会这么做。需要查看直接背景。

;

;;人们何时选择关注根本原因以及何时不关注根本原因，这很能说明问题，而且通常可以表明他们的同情心在哪里。;;;

;当然，我能理解。对所有仇恨犯罪使用相同的标准和方法当然非常重要。人们不想尝试以我们一直在讨论的方式来解释针对犹太人的仇恨犯罪，但对于针对其他群体的仇恨犯罪则不会这样做。我同意你的观点，在某些情况下，人们会做出选择。

;

;但仇恨犯罪并不是我真正所做的和我所想的，这也许有点明显。从根本上来说，我是一名历史学家，我可以将我们今天所思考的反犹太主义问题置于某种历史背景中。我不太喜欢关注仇恨犯罪的因果关系。这并不是因为这不是一组合理的问题；而是因为它不是一个合理的问题。是的，我认为你提出了重要的问题，但这并不是我真正所做的。

;

;回到反犹太主义的不同定义，以及将当前时刻置于某种背景中的一种方式 -我认为犹太人争论什么是反犹太主义、什么不是反犹太主义并不新鲜，而且犹太人所说的反犹太主义的含义随着时间的推移而发生了变化。这些争论是漫长历史的最新迭代，可以追溯到十八世纪八十年代反犹太主义一词开始普遍使用的时候。

;

;当它第一次普遍使用时，当然是在西方在欧洲，它的含义比此后要严格得多。那么，反犹太运动是真正的德国运动，它自称为反犹太联盟。他们对犹太人的公民平等提出了质疑。人们普遍认为反犹太主义就是与此相关的。这是关于犹太人不应该与其他臣民享有平等的想法。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;
;

;

;现在，非凡的后果之一是在西方，俄罗斯的大屠杀并没有被视为反犹太主义。他们是野蛮的，他们是中世纪的，他们是不文明的。但由于俄罗斯的犹太人没有被剥夺的权利，这些大屠杀并不符合反犹太主义的含义。谈论这一点的目的是说，反犹太主义的含义随着时间的推移而发生了变化，而我们最近的辩论只是漫长历史中的最新阶段。

;

;;今天的大部分内容都是基于关于以色列，这并不是说如果没有以色列就不会有反犹太主义者。您是否将 1948 年之后的时期视为反犹太主义时期？;

;
;
;

;好的，那就这样了一个非常大的问题。

;

;;你有三十秒的时间来回答它。;

;

;我会用俳句的形式来回答。这个问题有不同的维度。我曾写过反犹太主义是文化中的一个蓄水池，是可供借鉴的。这是一个已经建立了几个世纪、甚至几千年的水库。其中包括三个关键要素：一是犹太教已被基督教所取代的观念（即犹太人具有特殊性和狭隘道德的观念就是这一观念的结果之一）；二是犹太教已被基督教所取代的观念。其次，认为犹太人永远是阴谋家，总是在做一些违背公共利益的事情；第三，犹太人与金钱的联系。几个世纪以来，这些想法在多种政治背景下被重新利用。我们看到它们在针对以色列的一些反犹太主义攻击中被重新利用。

;

;美国、德国、英国和其他地方的多项民意调查显示，坚定的意识形态反犹太主义者的百分比相对较小，但关于犹太人的负面刻板印象和叙述在文化中的传播程度要高得多、范围要广得多。在某些时刻，人们会利用这些想法，尤其是在政治热点时刻，当这些想法似乎有用并且它们似乎可以解释某些事情时。是的，存在反犹太主义者，即具有反犹太世界观的意识形态坚定的个人和团体，但更常见的是利用文化中反犹太主义的个人。这就是我们在以色列周围看到的反犹太主义。

;

;;今天，我认为人们会从唐纳德·特朗普的在线追随者以及其他人那里看到这种右翼反犹太主义。还有左翼反犹太主义。然后是中东某些团体的反犹太主义，例如哈马斯，我认为在美国政治背景下，这些团体更多地与左派联系在一起，但如果你真正看看他们对同性恋者的想法，他们似乎右翼。您认为这些不同的反犹太主义在某种程度上是截然不同的吗？;

;

;我想认为它们是截然不同的。你们拥有借鉴共同文化的独特政治传统。关于反犹太主义的写作有一个传统，就是简单地强调这些长期的连续性。我认为，作为一名历史学家，这无助于人们理解特定事件发生时的情况，而且还可能导致人们误解当前时刻。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;例如，看一下将 10 月 7 日大屠杀事件描述为大屠杀的非常容易理解的描述。很容易理解为什么人们利用犹太人的集体记忆来描述这些事件。然而，在俄罗斯和后来在波兰发生的大屠杀中，犹太人是一个种族化的少数群体，相对弱势、脆弱，针对他们的暴力是为了让他们恢复原状。针对以色列人的暴力是可怕的。但称其为大屠杀并没有看到它们发生的非常不同的背景，在一个犹太人占多数的国家，他们拥有国家权力。从这些角度来看，如果有人确实想谈论大屠杀，人们就会关注;Huwara; 今年早些时候。

;

;;也许这导致了当前反犹太主义抬头的复杂情况。 10月7日之后，所有西方主要大国都坚定地站在以色列一边，对犹太人民和犹太国家的政治支持非常强大。这是人们难以掌握反犹太主义程度的原因之一。他们说，“美国两个政党的人都支持犹太人、支持以色列”等等。;

;
;
;

;不仅是西方列强坚定地站在以色列一边，而且西方列强在其内部政策中也非常明确地打击反犹太主义。拜登提出了打击反犹太主义的战略计划。在英国，政府资助犹太机构所在建筑物的安全。它正在帮助资助议会大厦旁边的大屠杀纪念项目。德国政府非常坚决地致力于防止德国社会再次出现反犹太主义。

;

;这在历史上是前所未有的。如果我们回到两次世界大战期间，欧洲政府要么明确对犹太人怀有敌意，要么在他们面临迫害时对他们漠不关心。这表明的事情之一是美国和欧洲的主流犹太社区经常与政府和当权者结盟的方式。这并不是说没有与其他少数族裔结盟，但这些少数族裔经常遭受痛苦和磨损。犹太人建立的纵向联盟在某种程度上使他们容易受到同情巴勒斯坦人、对以色列或其支持者几乎没有同情心的激进团体的攻击。这些纵向联盟为以色列以外的犹太人提供了一些回报和一些安全，但它们也带来了危险。

;

;;为什么它带来的危险必然需要受到保护？;

;

;如果人们认为犹太人受到其他群体没有的保护，就会带来危险。它带来了危险，因为它激怒了那些反对国家或体制的人们，无论他们如何看待它。左翼人士有时会以阴谋的方式理解这一点。许多参与巴勒斯坦权利运动的人也参与了围绕种族和社会正义的更广泛的政治活动。尽管犹太人和其他种族少数群体之间存在团结点，但以色列-巴勒斯坦问题的影响也使其他团结变得越来越难建立。

;

;;感觉有点像第二十二条军规，表明二十世纪的犹太人面临广泛的反犹太主义，面临大屠杀，然后作为回应寻求政治联盟，但现在他们不喜欢这样做。我想我对关注反犹太主义的任何既定原因的担忧是，这似乎有点像如果你这样做就会受到诅咒，如果你不这样做也会受到诅咒。;

;

;这与因果关系无关。这是关于思考动态是如何产生的。人们正在做出政治选择。联盟会建立，联盟也会破裂。它试图理解这种动态。它并不是想说，“嗯，这些纵向联盟是反犹太主义的一个原因”，但我是说，在全社会反种族主义动员不断加强的时代，这些纵向联盟揭示了犹太人和其他种族群体所采取的不同策略。少数民族。这回答了你关于犹太人在许多国家的地位的悖论的问题，因为他们感到恐惧，而目前反犹太事件正在急剧增加。我一直试图谈论的是如何理解这一点。 ♦

;上周，以色列的一次空袭杀死了电视记者穆罕默德·阿布·哈塔布 (Mohammed Abu Hatab) 以及他的十一位家人在加沙南部的家中。据保护记者委员会称，他是在当前冲突中确认死亡的第三十六位媒体成员。这个数字稳步上升。绝大多数是当地加沙人，他们试图在持续的轰炸中掩盖这场危机。直到最近，还没有新的外国记者或独立组织被允许见证正在发生的事情。

;

;自 10 月初以来，我一直试图从远处捕捉加沙生活的片段，主要是通过 WhatsApp 与那里的人和巴勒斯坦裔美国人。 It seemed that every other person knew someone who had died.

;

;Hossin Shaqur, an insurance broker who lives in Santa Barbara, California, was born in the Jabalia refugee camp, in northern Gaza, after his family was displaced in 1948 from a village that is now part of southern Israel. In 1967, some of the family moved to Qatar and eventually to the United States, but his sister, his nieces and nephews, his cousins, and his aunts and uncles remained in Jabalia. Since Israel's bombing campaign began, Hossin told me, he has been able to confirm that nearly seventy of his relatives have been killed. The neighborhood his mother's family lived in was levelled. The last he heard, his sister was still alive. “But I don't know if she's alive right now,” he told me over the phone. “We are glued to the TV. You watch the news for a couple of hours, do something, and you come back and something new has happened. It repeats itself.”

;

;A few days after the bombing started, many Gazans thought they might find safety in the south. Noor Harazeen, a young journalist based in Gaza City, left her home and travelled with her husband and their children to Deir al-Balah, in the middle of the Strip. When Noor messaged me from there, she had not had a drink of water for more than twenty-four hours. There were almost no potable sources; she and her family had been subsisting on juice.

;

;Soon after Israel launched its war on Gaza, in response to Hamas's October 7th attack, military planes dropped leaflets in the north, including in Gaza City, warning residents—about a million people—to evacuate. Families struggled to decide what to do. Almost immediately afterward, an air strike hit a road in Gaza City that was considered a “safe route,” reportedly killing seventy people. (Hamas blamed Israel for the attack, though the Israel Defense Forces has denied responsibility.)

;

;Even in the south, bombings seemed random. One late afternoon in the first week, Alaa Zaher Ahmed, a third-year medical student, was designing a poster for breast-cancer awareness in her room in Khan Younis. “Suddenly, everything started shaking and I found myself in darkness,” she told me over voice notes. “Couldn't see anything.” First, she noticed that she was still breathing, and then that she couldn't move one hand, and then that her head hurt. She touched it and felt on her fingertips “a viscous fluid.” Blood. Alaa tried to move, but her legs were pinned down and she couldn't feel them. Above her was something mysterious, heavy, concrete.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It may have been ten minutes, she guessed, before she heard muffled voices that seemed to grow louder. Alaa started to scream and knock on the concrete above her. A neighbor pulled her out of the rubble. Rescue teams and relatives continued to dig through the wreckage. After several hours, they unearthed most of the rest of her family: her mother, brother, and nephew, all dead. Her home, which was three stories, “went down like biscuits,” she told me. Amid the caved-in remnants, the few things that remained recognizable—a mattress, sofa, pink cloth—were blanketed in dust.

;

;The United Nations estimates that more than half of Gaza's population has been displaced since the beginning of the war. People have been scattered into preëxisting refugee camps, or to homes of friends or relatives in different cities, or to schools or hospitals. Adnan Sawada's family is one of the scattered. Adnan, fifty-five years old, runs a transportation company and lives in Maryland. His family, who live in Sheikh Radwan, in northern Gaza City, decided to move after the leaflets sprinkled down. They took a mattress, some clothes, toys for the kids, food, and ended up, like Noor, in Deir al-Balah.

;

;Adnan hasn't seen any of his siblings in thirteen years. Months ago, he spoke to his eldest brother, Shaban, over the phone. Shaban was giddy with excitement; his son was to be married, and soon he would have a grandchild. “I'm old and enjoying life,” Adnan remembered him saying.

;
;
;

;What Adnan knows, as relayed to him by his nephew, is this: On the afternoon of October 16th, Shaban and another brother were talking outside a house. The brother went inside. Suddenly, there was a blast, and everything shuddered. When the brother emerged, he found Shaban on the ground, bloodied, one leg gone. Shaban was rushed to the hospital, but by the time the doctor could see him, he had died. “He died from bleeding, obviously,” Adnan told me, “but the whole reason was the bomb.”

;
;
;

;The long wait to be seen by a doctor had become common by then. Gaza City's Al-Shifa hospital, the largest in the Strip, was buckling under an inflow of injured men, women, children, and babies. Tarneem Hammad, a writer based in Gaza who works with humanitarian-aid groups, told me that doctors were describing the hospital as a “slaughterhouse.” There were too many dead people arriving, or unable to be saved. With supplies running low, some people were cut and sutured without anesthesia.

;

;“Journalists are sleeping on the floors of the hospital,” Noor told me, on the morning of October 17th. “It might be at least safer than other places.” That calculation changed rapidly. Later that day, a blast at Al-Ahli Arab hospital, also in Gaza City, killed around a hundred people; the cause remains unclear, though evidence suggests a rocket launched by a Palestinian militant group. Recently, a doctor in Gaza sent me a video of smoke ballooning into the sky after an Israeli strike near Al-Quds hospital. Last week, Israel hit near the entrance of Al-Shifa hospital. (A spokesperson for the IDF said it will “strike Hamas wherever necessary.”)

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Not long after Noor arrived in Deir al-Balah, I received another note from her. “You can sleep and never wake up,” she told me. “You can sleep and wake up on the news of the killing of your family members. No one is safe if he is Gazan or a foreigner. No one is safe if he is a citizen or a militant. No one is safe if he's a doctor, journalist, nothing.”

;

;As the days went on, some Gazans who had initially evacuated decided to return home. Bombs were falling on those who sought shelter in the south, too. The Gaza Strip is only a hundred and forty square miles; it seemed to matter little where one was. Tarneem told me that she and her family made the “difficult decision” to stay put. “The calculation here right now in Gaza is either you have been bombed, or you are just waiting to be bombed,” she said in a voice note. “So if I were to live my last days before being bombed, I just want to be at my home around my family.”

;

;Four weeks ago, Nabil Alshurafa, a medical researcher living outside Chicago, was on the phone with his mother, Naela, a retired sixty-six-year-old hair stylist who had recently travelled from California to northern Gaza to visit her own mother. Nabil could hear the pounding of bombs in the background. When Nabil was a child, he and his family were living in Kuwait, where his father was a doctor. Nabil was a US citizen, the only one in his family at the time, and when the first Gulf War broke out, the American government quickly airlifted them back to safety. He assumed something similar might happen now.

;

;The day after the Hamas massacre, Naela had gotten into a taxi and raced south, toward Rafah Crossing, the only access point on Gaza's border with Egypt. The gate was overrun and she was unable to get out. Two days later, she made a second attempt. She was in line to get her passport stamped, just ten minutes away from Egypt, when an explosion shook the border gate. Nabil heard about the blast from his uncle, who didn't know if Naela was alive; it was hours before Nabil heard that his mother was safe.

;

;Panicked and desperate, Nabil filled out a State Department crisis intake form. The e-mail response he eventually received advised American citizens in Gaza to consider going to Rafah. A week later, when I spoke to Nabil, he was crying. Naela was still inside the Strip, along with some four hundred other US citizens, while Israel hit Rafah repeatedly. For almost a month, not a single American was able to leave. On November 1st, as legal and public pressure mounted, ;President Biden; announced that the evacuation of American citizens would begin. Naela was on the list, and the next day, she walked into Egypt. Her family remained in Gaza.

;

;Even before the war, Gaza was one of the most difficult places in the world to get into and out of. There hasn't been a functioning airport since 2002, when Israel bulldozed the runway. After Hamas's electoral victory in 2006, Israel implemented a blockade that severely limits the movement of people and goods. Sixty-five per cent of people in Gaza live in poverty, and around half are unemployed. Families with means and opportunity try to send at least one child abroad to study and work. Yahia Abuhashem, a thirty-four-year-old data scientist in Chicago, left Gaza fifteen years ago and hasn't seen his parents or siblings since. One brother is a dentist, another an engineer, and a sister is a paralegal—they are lucky to have such jobs, he told me, or to have any jobs at all. Still, he sends several hundred dollars from the US regularly to supplement their incomes.

;
;
;

;Yahia's parents' apartment building, in the Tel al-Hawa neighborhood of Gaza City, was struck in the 2021 war, he told me. (At the time, Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International found what appeared to be a pattern of the IDF targeting residential buildings. “In some cases entire families were buried beneath the rubble when the buildings they lived in collapsed,” Amnesty wrote.) His parents spent two and a half years renovating and rebuilding, and, this August, they finally moved back home. As soon as the recent bombardment started, the family left again and headed south: some to Khan Younis, some to Rafah, and some to Nuseirat. Tel al-Hawa was bombed soon after, and again several days after that.

;

;According to the United Nations, forty-two per cent of Gaza's housing units were destroyed by Israeli bombing in the first three weeks of the assault. That is already a stale figure. It's difficult to know how many people are underneath the resulting rubble, how many of them might still be alive. In an interview with Sky News, Mark Regev, a former Israeli Ambassador to the United Kingdom and a government adviser, insisted that Israel doesn't target civilian structures. “War is very, very difficult,” he said. When the journalist pushed him on mounting civilian deaths and residential buildings, he responded, “They are Hamas targets.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;On a recent evening, I visited Dorgham Abusalim, who works in communications, in Washington, DC He left Gaza in 2006 to study abroad and has returned only a couple of times. In his living room, the television was set to Al Jazeera Arabic. He pointed to his laptop, which, he told me, was usually tuned into other news channels, too. As we spoke, his hand never strayed far from his cell phone, on the seat next to him. He was part of several chat groups that delivered updates from the ground—a stream of information that came through slightly faster than Western media reported it. A head start of even a couple of minutes meant less time between panic and relief, or panic and grief.

;

;Two nights earlier, at 1:30 ;AM;, his phone dinged with notices about Deir al-Balah, where his parents and a sister live. Dozens of people had been killed. Frantic, Dorgham called his brother in Canada, who tried his parents' number repeatedly. Dorgham tried, too, but the call didn't go through. For hours, he scrolled through each update that came in. He zoomed in on images of familiar streets, searching for a flash of a neighbor's house, or his school, or his own home.

;

;Finally, around four-thirty, his brother called and told him to go to sleep: “They're alive.”

;

;“I'm up & writing this on the sounds of bombings,” Tarneem, the aid worker, told me in a message over WhatsApp on October 24th. It was the middle of the night. “We're tired. I ;am; tired,” she said. Food was low; she had not been drinking enough water. “I do not sleep, the sounds of explosions I hear all day and night are getting into my head.”

;

;That same day, Noor, the journalist, sent me a voice message. “I'm alive, actually,” she said, with what sounded like surprise. She was still in Deir al-Balah. “It translates into the city of dates,” she said, “because it's full of date trees.” The attacks had intensified in the past few days, and she had been reporting from Shuhada Al-Aqsa hospital. “We've seen so much things we're not supposed to see,” she said. Bodies, injuries, children, women. “Yeah, it has been really hard.”

;

;Recent satellite images of some parts of Gaza reveal the aftermath from above. Most of the once white rooftops are blanketed in gray. Blocks of buildings that once stood appear now as smudges. The Strip is pockmarked with craters. Last week, Yoav Gallant, Israel's defense minister, said that Israel had dropped more than ten thousand bombs on just Gaza City, an area smaller than Manhattan. The air, I've gathered from several reports and from people I've spoken with, smells of smoke, dust, rotting corpses, sewage.

;

;Yahia, like many other Palestinian Americans, has been trying to contact his representatives in Congress to plead for help to keep his family safe. The week after the bombardment started, he reached out to his senator, Tammy Duckworth. He shared with me the letter he received in response. It opened with “Thank you for contacting me about Hamas' horrific terrorist attacks against Israel. I condemn, in the strongest possible terms, Hamas' brutal violence that began on October 7, 2023.”

;
;
;

;More than ten thousand people have died in Israel's retaliatory attack, according to Gaza's Health Ministry. Recently, President Biden said that he has “no confidence in the number that the Palestinians are using.” In an apparent response, the Gazan authorities published more than two hundred pages of names of the dead, along with their ID numbers, gender, and age. The staggering number of children killed—more than four thousand as of this writing—prompted ;UNICEF; to call the situation “a growing stain on our collective conscience.”

;

;Late on the evening of October 27th, Gaza went dark. Israel cut telecommunication services; no one could use the Internet or the phone. Media and international organizations announced that they had lost touch with their colleagues. All the people I was talking to on WhatsApp stopped responding.

;

;That weekend, Israeli troops pushed into Gaza. After nearly two days, reportedly under US pressure, Israel restored lines of communication. (Other blackouts have followed.) Everyone I had spoken with on the ground slowly started getting back to me. In the following days, Israeli bombs wiped out parts of the Jabalia refugee camp, near where Hossin's sister lives. Tarneem sent a message, her voice quiet and shaky. She was sick. When the phone lines were cut, she told me, neighbors carried the injured and dead in donkey carts. For the first time since we started talking, she admitted, “I'm not handling anything emotionally.”

;

;Just prior to this article's publication, Nabil sent me another update: an airstrike had killed his wife's uncle and aunt, along with three of their children and three of their grandchildren. ♦

;;I. THE LAUNCH;

;

;Like other expeditions of its time, the eighteenth-century voyage of the Fortitude had lofty goals. My hundred-and-forty-foot man-of-war sought to make the first mission to the South Pole, a feat that would bring pride to England. But I planned to do more than that. On the way home, we'd stop in Brazil to teach its people about Christianity and mirrors, then on to Argentina to take its tin, and Tahiti to kiss its women. After an ale or two, I would even boast that we'd locate the lost city of Atlantis, schedule permitting.

;

;At twenty-eight, I was young for a captain. I've been described as an imposing figure of five feet six, with a deep voice and penetrating eyes. My name is Herbrerm Enrory Howrard Pinkleton, but to friends I'm simply Herbrerm EH Pinkleton.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;On the day of the launch, a crowd of onlookers gathered. I remember gazing upon my wife and children—but then looking past them to my father. Henry Horatrio “Warlord” Pinkleton was a heavily decorated admiral of the Royal Navy, famous for having defeated a Spanish armada with just a small fleet of English ships and, separately, for having strangled a Spanish man with his bare hands (not a military operation). I saw his gaze narrow as my men struggled to assemble the spare hawsers. Experienced seamen were in high demand at the time, and I'd been left with a bunch of landlubbers, green hands, and shore dunces.

;

;I didn't have much experience myself, having never technically captained a ship. I'd been first mate once, but that was on a scoot over to Ireland. I was fully aware that the Crown had hurried me into the position because they were sick of hearing about how great tin was and how much of it there was just sitting around in Argentina. And I was damn determined to someday pull back into this harbor with a boat packed with the shiny stuff and my father looking on.

;
;

;;II. THE SQUALL;

;
;
;

;Just after noon on the 2nd of May, the mud-covered anchor of the Fortitude was hauled up and lashed to the bulwarks, and we were off to the South Pole, all sails trimmed in the breeze. I gazed across the Thames, thinking of the challenges that lay ahead. Especially Cape Horn, with its dreaded graybeards (waves that were said to be at least eighty feet tall), and the harsh winters we would spend on the ice, living off seals that we'd beaten to death. I also thought of my wife and seven children, still waving from shore, wondering how they would fare during my three-year absence.

;

;Good fortune did not accompany the launch. My first mate, Teeshy McGann, informed me that an unexpected storm was moving in from the east. He suggested that we lower sail and wait it out, maybe even inch back into the dock. “Lower no sails!” I cried, loud enough for everyone onshore to hear. “Let's give this squall a punch in the mouth!”

;
;
;

;As soon as the devastating gust fell upon us, I shouted, “Luff into the wind, boys!” and grabbed the wheel myself. And then a moment later, changing my mind, I called out, “Wait, actually bear away, you idiots!” This left the ship in a vulnerable position, and she lurched leeward so hard that the tips of her masts dipped into the water. We all clung to the railings. The livestock below deck were thrown about, and men had to cover their faces as mean, biting hogs rained down. McGann bellowed, “Get to the lifeboats!”

;

;But I wanted my ship to be light and quick now more than ever. “Actually, cut free the lifeboats!” I cried. “And throw all stores of food and water overboard.” I felt pride that these commands came out with no lisp. I wondered whether my father had noticed. There was nothing to be angry about.

;

;The Fortitude continued to be tossed about, with some men being thrown head first into the wooden toilets on deck, where they suffocated and died. This was such a common occurrence that it became the origin of the expression, “I'm so busy that my head is buried in feces with my legs kicking around in the air.”

;

;I had a decision to make. My ship could either return to dock and be repaired while I suffered humiliation before my father and the growing crowd. Or we could press on toward the South Pole and Argentina, with its shiny tin, and Tahiti's women, with their non-British lips. To me, there was no decision. ♦

;众所周知，电影行业不稳定，对于任何敢于思考的公司来说，这条道路尤其危险电影既是一门艺术，也是一门商业。因此，;时代精神电影;，最杰出的艺术之一 -电影发行商刚刚迎来成立三十五周年，Metrograph 恰如其分地通过 ;为期一个月的系列;影院内和在线影片，重点介绍 Zeitgeist 的一些最重要的影片。甚至在我成为影评人之前，当我很少关注电影的商业方面时，我就一直在远处尊重时代精神。碰巧，该公司是由我的高中朋友艾米丽·罗素 (Emily Russo) 和南希·格斯特曼 (Nancy Gerstman) 共同创立的，我一直对公司成功发行独立和国际电影感到特别高兴，否则这些电影可能会消失在美国完全没有见过。

;

;Zeitgeist 发行的有影响力的作品数量太多、种类繁多，无法用简短的专栏来全面介绍。有人可能会提到托德·海恩斯 (Todd Haynes) 于 1991 年推出的第一部长片《毒药》(Poison)，该片不仅让这位导演名声大噪，但却帮助发起了新酷儿电影运动。或者人们可以注意到它的一系列巧妙的纪录片，包括托尼·布巴的“;布拉多克上的闪电，;”;阿涅斯·瓦尔达;的《拾穗者》和我，”以及伊冯·雷纳的“;特权;”。或者人们还记得，时代精神凭借贾樟柯的《世界》发行了二十一世纪最好的电影之一。但是，在我看来，没有什么成就比该公司在引起美国观众的注意方面所发挥的重要作用更大了，他是最伟大的电影制作人之一，;阿巴斯·基亚罗斯塔米;，随着 1997 年电影《樱桃之味》的上映（ ，现在正在 Criterion Channel 和 Max 上播出）。

;

;与您可能听说的相反，十九世纪九十年代对于发行独立和国际电影来说是一个糟糕的时期。这十年被称为美国独立电影繁荣时期的声誉主要适用于接近好莱坞、以商业为导向的独立电影，例如“;变色龙街;，”Zeinabu irene Davis 的“;补偿;”和埃里克·门德尔松的“朱迪·柏林”——要么未发行，要么严重未发行。此外，这十年来许多最好的国际电影也仍未发行。令人震惊的是，菲利普·科林的“;伊曼纽尔·康德的最后日子;”甚至;让-吕克·戈达尔;的《新浪潮》（阿兰·德龙主演！）;仍未;在这里上映。

;

;三十年前独立电影发行业务看起来与现在有很大不同。如今，从纽约电影节到商业上映的管道已畅通无阻，流程也很快，但在那时，这更多的是流水账。如今，社交媒体迅速引起轰动，并以光速传播批评热情。那时，网络生活主要是电子邮件——在电影界，这主要意味着影迷能够比以前更快地私下抱怨。基亚罗斯塔米的电影是在那种荒凉的环境中兴起的，考虑到他现在无可争议的声望，很难记住他的职业生涯在阴影中徘徊了多久。

;

;出生于 1940 年的基亚罗斯塔米从那时起就一直在拍电影。 1970 年拍摄了他的第一部长片，并于 1973 年拍摄了他的第一部电影。作为《电影手册》的读者，我从 1990 年左右就开始了解他的作品。他的第一部突破性电影是 1987 年的剧情片《哪里》是朋友家吗？我还记得读过他 1989 年的纪录片《家庭作业》；他的第一部广受好评的国际杰作是1990年的纪录片《特写》，直到1999年才在这里上映。纽约电影节于1992年放映了他的故事片《生活继续》和《穿过橄榄树》 1994 年。到了 90 年代中期，看过他的一两部电影后，我确信基亚罗斯塔米是最具原创性、概念上最大胆、美学上最精致的电影制作人之一，但令我沮丧的是，他的电影在中国却没有出现。美国市场。 《穿过橄榄树》最初被收购并在美国院线上映，但收购它的公司米拉麦克斯却对其表现不佳。这部电影看起来一定是在艺术影院受欢迎的一个不错的选择：尽管有一些元小说的手法，但它是一部充满渴望和温暖的喜剧爱情片。但米拉麦克斯似乎临阵退缩了。 1995 年 2 月，这部电影在一家不起眼的剧院进行了一场几乎没有广告的预演。它继续使这部电影在一段不合时宜的时间内远离家庭视频市场。作为一家小型（现已解散）的美国发行商，我拜访了基亚罗斯塔米早期电影的销售代理商。发行公司希望发行基亚罗斯塔米的一部电影，但该机构告诉我需要大量预付款，而且公司没有预算，所以就这样了。我讲这个故事是为了表明，1997 年 Zeitgeist 收购了《樱桃之味》时，它的赌注是重大的。这部电影在当年的戛纳电影节上获得了最高奖项——金棕榈奖，发行商也因此获得了大奖。距离该片在纽约电影节美国首映还有不到一周的时间；如此高调的影片无疑对时代精神提出了很高的要求，尤其是由于影片的性质和主题。

;
;
;

;《樱桃之味》讲述了讲述了一位名叫巴迪先生（Homayoun Ershadi 饰）的中年男子的故事，他在德黑兰及其周边地区开车，接载了一系列乘客，希望他们能够快速接受他提供的一份工作。他打算当晚躺在附近乡村的一条偏僻的沟渠里，服用过量的安眠药，并想雇人早上过来检查一下。如果他还活着，他们可以帮助他脱离困境；如果没有，他们可以用铲子泥土覆盖他的尸体。巴迪从未透露过他的动机，但他显然是在安排自己的自杀，如果自杀不成功的话，也不会被发现，因此他需要陌生人的服务。他愿意出高价，提供的金额相当于体力劳动者六个月的收入。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;几乎所有影片的动作都发生在巴迪的车内或附近，并且大部分动作都是对话——扩展的讨论场景，在车里，在城外的丘陵乡村地区巴迪试图连续说服三名乘客完成这项工作。一名是伊朗陆军的年轻应征入伍者；一个是神学院的学生；第三位是一位在自然历史博物馆担任动物标本剥制师的老人。当巴迪为一份他拒绝预先描述的工作提供大笔资金时，他的态度有些谨慎和控制欲，但又暗暗绝望。他的说服之网是精心编织的——他编织的一部分是他对对话者的生活暗示的好奇心，他引出他们的需要的故事。

;

;换句话说，巴迪是一名记者，并且他遇到的人都有自己的麻烦：这名士兵是库尔德人，他在自己的乡村家乡感受到了两伊战争的影响；这位修士是一名阿富汗人，他选择离开饱受战争蹂躏的国家；标本剥制师有一个生病的孩子需要昂贵的治疗。当然，基亚罗斯塔米是一位准纪录片导演，不仅体现在他对这个好奇故事的构建，也体现在他的拍摄中，从他对发生行动的贫瘠、沙质和险恶的农村地区的看法开始。 《樱桃的味道》是他版本的《我对她了解的两三件事》的一部分，这是一个关于工业化和现代化变革的故事，它带来了新形式的孤立、挫败和绝望。基亚罗斯塔米的拍摄具有纪录片般的专注力——对风景和面孔、对情境和想法——这与电视剧渐进的、调查性的、观察性的姿态相匹配。

;

;然而，在其表面之下却潜藏着彻底的狂野和彻底的讽刺。首先，自杀不仅是禁忌，而且违反了伊斯兰教法（神学院生自己也这么说），因此，《樱桃之味》不仅被禁止在伊朗放映，而且几乎被禁止出口（因此来自戛纳）。因此，这是一个明显反抗的故事，是对另一个包含公民和宗教权威的权威的诉求。事实上，这是一部道德和身体自主权的电影，是关于存在或不存在的终极自由的电影——一种将自杀作为自由的愿景，接续了安德烈·马尔罗和存在主义者的中断。与此同时，这种自由的愿景涉及的不是控制，而是放弃控制，屈服于存在的硬币翻转，屈服于过量服用是否有效的随机问题。带着讽刺性的不确定性和果断的优柔寡断的暗流，《樱桃的味道》演变成一部奇怪的电影：这是一部自杀喜剧，类似于杰里·刘易斯导演的最后一部电影，“;崩溃;。”其极其恐怖的幽默的一个例子是巴迪在一条毗邻陡峭沙崖的狭窄道路上行驶时的一瞬间的分心：正当他准备不小心翻倒时，他的轮胎卡在了沙子里。 （该序列在主题上与;刘易斯电影中的一个;押韵。）

;

;甚至标题事实证明很讽刺。它暗示着基本的感官愉悦、赋予生命意义的记忆宝库，并以一种引力将人拉回到日常活动中。然而，巴迪唤起的最美好的回忆绝非一碗樱桃：他记得自己的兵役经历，他特别将这项活动描述为需要做好杀人准备的活动。就此而言，《樱桃之味》中还有另一个疯狂的悖论——它的结局并没有剧透。我不会说巴迪会怎样，但无论如何，这都不是结局；相反，基亚罗斯塔米跳出了动作框架，以一些摄制组的低保真视频作为结束，视频中导演呼唤一队行进的士兵回到原来的位置进行另一次拍摄。他以看似无限倒退的方式结束，模拟了官方批准和授权、国家批准和宗教祝福的处理死亡的权力的现实。

;

;在 1998 年发布时， 《樱桃之味》的院线票房只有三十万美元。但它被国家影评人协会评为年度最佳外语片，并在该类别中获得亚军 ;纽约影评人协会;，排名第四（仅领先于“;好家伙;”）;;乡村之声;民意调查< /a>; 十年来最好的电影。简而言之，从那时起，直到他的职业生涯结束——他于 2016 年去世——我们再也无法否认基亚罗斯塔米了。 《Close-Up》于 1999 年迟来发行；他1999年的电影《风将载着我们》于次年立即在这里上映。从那时起，他的作品一直是美国艺术界的中流砥柱，也是美国评论家和电影制片人的主要参考。时代精神也许并没有发布它，但该公司创造了历史。 ♦

;让我们面对现实吧，你的二十多岁很难;艰难;。在没有安全网的情况下进入“现实世界”是您必须经历的最可怕的旅程之一。而且，如果您最近读过博客或浏览过 Twitter，您就会知道这对于 FGK（以前的天才儿童）来说尤其困难。很有可能，您认识一位以前的天才儿童。哎呀，你甚至可能就是其中之一！如果您不确定，请不要担心。我们将通过十一个迹象为您详细说明您曾经是一名天才儿童。 （第四名会让你震惊！）

;

;;11.您在小学时就达到了巅峰。;

;

;在以前的天才儿童中，提早达到巅峰是很常见的。感觉最好的日子已经过去可能会导致焦虑和压力。你把四年级的成绩压垮了，这不是你的错！

;

;;10。你感到精疲力竭。;

;

;你还年轻，但你已经担心自己没有什么可以奉献了。 “拿出电子游戏，把它们带给我。我整天都躺在床上。” - 以前的天才儿童（哇！）

;

;;9.有人告诉你你很特别。;

;
;
;

;也许有人告诉你你是一位出色的读者。也许你被称为“数学高手”。也许一位几百岁的巫师来找你，说你是天选之人，注定要保护八界免受难以言喻的邪恶侵害。呃，你好？有人听说过“孩子就是孩子”吗？！

;

;;8.你承受的压力太大了。;

;

;“把 A+ 带回家，马特！” “露西，考试取得好成绩！” “学习神秘艺术，阻止夜凤凰毁灭我们所有人，迪伦！他吃了你的父母，他也会回来找你的！”在再次对孩子们说这些话之前，让我们先检查一下自己，好吗？

;

;;7.你没有达到期望。;

;

;让我猜一下。您在十二岁时;;还没有成为一名医生吗？你;不能;施展隐藏咒来抵御那个村庄的死亡收割者吗？你已经尽力了！自爱是关键。

;

;;6.您希望能够重温童年。;

;

;事实是，您不能。因为你的时间咒语很糟糕。这也是师父这么快就放弃你的原因之一。他的新学徒是否已经召唤出超龙也没关系。你最多能做的就是在你的 Rite Aid 轮班之间打开一个空白并尖叫，“操斯宾塞！”进去。 “操你个十二岁的，召唤龙的混蛋！”

;

;;5。您有偏头痛。;

;
;
;

;这对您来说是天才儿童的倦怠！或者也许这只是你与夜凤凰的心灵联系。 （如果你被传送到一个黑暗、尖叫的沼泽，那么你绝对是一个以前的天才儿童，哈哈。）忽略那些噩梦，回去吸精灵大麻吧。

;

;;4。你非常内向。;

;

;你拒绝制定计划吗？你用十字弓击落了所有的邮隼吗？也许你甚至在门上施了隐形咒来避开客人。 ;敲，敲;——猜猜有人绕过了这个咒语！但你不在乎。无论如何你都会忽略它——;敲，敲！;到底是谁？

;

;;3.您不想帮助别人。;

;
;
;

;
;
;

;;2. You experience emotional swings.;

;

;What do you mean, Master is dead? How is that possi—he's supposed to be immortal. If you're a former gifted kid, chances are, this news will rock your world. But it doesn't matter. It's not up to you to help some kid with his dumbass virgin quest. Besides, you're not master material anyway. [Hits elf-weed blunt.]

;

;;1. You learn that being special is a choice.;

;
;
;

;Sooo Spencer's a little prick. He's going off about how you were “never the Chosen One.” How he heard you were a “crap apprentice” and “couldn't do time spells for shit.” Wow. Future burnout alert! But then Spencer gets quiet. He opens a portal and stares into your soul. He tells you that maybe you were never special. But maybe you can be. Maybe you can help him save a world that he still cares about.为什么？ Because he believes in you. Not the who you were, but the who you might become. Your breath catches. You look into his eyes. You glance at the crossbow on your wall. You grab your cloak. You step through the portal. You choose yourself. ♦

;On October 17th, ten days after Hamas launched its ;attack on southern Israel;, a State Department official named Josh Paul quit his job and posted the resignation letter on LinkedIn. In Washington, sympathy with Israel was near-ubiquitous, and President Joe Biden's ;vigorous support; for the Israeli government had few public dissenters within the national-security state. This had the effect of drawing extra attention to Paul, who said he was resigning both because he disagreed with what the US had already done to back Israel and because he feared what would likely come next. “I believe to the core of my soul,” Paul wrote, “that the response Israel is taking, and with it the American support for both that response, and for the status quo of the occupation will only lead to more and deeper suffering for both the Israeli and Palestinian people—and is not in the long-term American interest.”

;

;The document spread quickly, and by the start of Israel's ground invasion of Gaza Paul was being interviewed on CNN, the BBC, PBS, and elsewhere, as the emblem of internal dissent. Shaven-headed and thick-necked, with an unexpected British accent, he spoke with the same clipped, rapid precision with which military spokesmen announce casualty reports. If you set aside what he was saying, he seemed, in appearance and manner, something like the opposite of a peacenik.

;

;He was also a former high-school classmate of mine. I remembered Paul as an intense, outdoorsy teen-ager who had moved from England to New York at the beginning of eighth grade, remained slightly aloof, and then returned to the United Kingdom for college. We had since lost touch, but I still kept track of him—he had gone to Iraq to work with George W. Bush's Coalition Provisional Authority, then spent the better part of a year in Ramallah, in the West Bank, working for a US-led project to build up the Palestinian Authority's security forces. Afterward, he spent a decade at the State Department working for the Bureau of Political-Military Affairs, also known as PM, which manages arms transfers to allies and partners, some of which have extensive histories of human-rights violations. Once, out with friends in New York, I had run into Paul as he was showing three Iraqi security officials a night out in the city. If he occupied a place in my imagination, it was an anachronistic one, as a sincere foot soldier of the American empire.

;

;The news of his resignation left me with a slightly dissonant feeling: If all of official Washington was behind Biden's Israel policy, why was ;this; the guy who wasn't? In Paul's resignation letter, he had alluded to the ethical complexities of arms-transfer work at the State Department: “In my 11 years I have made more moral compromises than I can recall, each heavily.” I reached out and, a few hours later, received a message from him on Signal: “Funny old world, isn't it?” Two weeks ago, I went down to Washington to meet him, and to try to gauge whether the rest of us, as Americans, should feel as implicated by the war as he did.

;

;When I met Paul, at an outdoor café in Friendship Heights, he didn't seem much cut loose from his former life. He was wearing a suit, and his demeanor was warm but not exactly relaxed. Texts and phone calls came from think tanks and university departments hoping to schedule events. He was still in a fight over bombs that were already being dropped. The day before, Paul said, he'd been to Capitol Hill for meetings and had stumbled upon a peace protest in a member's office. Then he'd headed over to his old haunt at the State Department, where pro-Palestine activists were protesting. “It was going on literally outside my old window,” he said. “So I knew that all my former colleagues were listening.” At one point, the demonstrators chanted, “Quit! Your! Jobs!”

;

;There was a generational arc to Paul's experience. Most of our high-school classmates graduated from college in 2000. Paul earned a master's degree at Georgetown, in national-security studies, and managed to get a job, via the Bush White House, with the Coalition Provisional Authority in Baghdad. “At the time, I would have said I was an adult, but looking back I was just an excited kid,” he said. Paul arrived in March, 2004, two weeks before the start of the First Battle of Fallujah. His assignment was to serve as a civilian adviser to the Iraqi Interior Ministry as it trained security forces. For a time, he flew twice a week from Baghdad to Fallujah to encourage the Marines, the Iraqi police, and the tribes to work together. “How did that go?” I asked. Paul said, “I mean, my immediate counterpart in the Iraqi Ministry of the Interior was assassinated.”

;

;The US had helped create a unit called the Iraqi police commandos, which eventually became the Iraqi Special Police, with the intent of taking over some of the missions of US Special Forces as they transitioned out. “It very quickly was taken over by former regime Baathists, who the US was very closely allied with and was embedding Special Forces advisers with, but who were committing torture, and all sorts of human-rights abuses, and extrajudicial killings,” Paul said. “But the American view was it was all right because these were our guys.” Seeing how that played out, he went on, “was something that made me very uneasy.”

;
;
;

;Elsewhere in the region, efforts to build a Palestinian state under the principles of the Oslo Accords were under way. Paul, who had written his master's thesis on Israeli counterterrorism, spent a year in Ramallah, working on an initiative to bolster Palestinian security forces based on the premise that “if we give Israel more security, then they will make concessions for peace.” The Israeli argument, Paul went on, was that what was holding the Palestinians back was a lack of prosperity, “and if we can open some trade routes then things would flourish.” But, in Ramallah, Paul came to doubt that this was the case. “Even with the privileges of being a Westerner there, with a government pass, able to go through the checkpoints, when you see the humiliations that Palestinians go through every day, you see how impossible it is.” There might be two towns right next to each other, tied by family, but there was no direct road to get from one to the other “because the road is now for settlers only.” Water was diverted; Palestinians with dry farms could look up at hilltops and see developments with swimming pools. Members of the Israel Defense Forces sometimes staged security raids in Palestinian communities. “The Israeli military took us on a tour of a neighborhood in Jenin, and they said, 'It's very dangerous, every time we come here, they shoot at us,' ” Paul recalled. “;Well, have you tried not going?;”

;

;Something about the way Paul said this—the sarcasm, as if it were all self-evident—reminded me of his adolescent self. He seemed to pull back, too. He had a tight line to walk—to sound not like he was making an a-priori ideological case for peace, as an activist might, but like his skepticism of supplying the Israeli military reflected the hard-won experience of the national-security state. Sometimes, when he spoke about Israel, I detected a political self-consciousness in the phrasing. “The Israeli story is an absolutely amazing one,” he said at one point, sounding a bit like an ambassador at a ribbon-cutting, “how it has transformed itself technologically and economically in seventy-five years.” At another point, he paused while mentioning the “horrors” of the Hamas attack, looked at my recorder, and said, “which of course I condemn.” He added, “One shouldn't have to say that, but one does.”

;
;
;

;The year in Ramallah had left him with the impression that security and prosperity for peace was an impossible proposition, because you could not have any of those things amid an occupation. “You cannot bomb the resistance out of the Palestinian people,” Paul said. “You can contain them, as Israel has done for a long time. But, if ultimately that is the path you take, it will not lead to security for the Israeli people.” Because, he went on, “if you bomb them continuously, and traumatize them continuously, and restrict them from leaving the land, and refuse them medical care, and control their electricity and water, they will hate you. In addition to my concern for Palestinian lives, my concern was and remains that Israel is not doing itself any favors here. That it is extending the trauma of the conflict to another generation of its own people.”

;

;The question of exactly how much the United States is implicated in the crimes or excesses of its allies is present in much of foreign policy, but perhaps nowhere is it as tangible as within the three-hundred-and-fifty-person Political-Military Bureau of the State Department. Many of its officials are affiliated with the military. “This is not an office that attracts a lot of hippies,” a former State Department official told me. In 2012, Paul joined PM as its director of congressional and public affairs, a position he held until his resignation, which meant that his job was to help manage relations with Capitol Hill and public messaging about decisions to send deadly weapons systems to sometimes questionable regimes. He was also involved in the approval process for major weapons sales. The laws and policies governing such arms deals require scrutiny of the human-rights records of the governments, militaries, and units receiving weapons, meaning that Paul was often immersed in debates over the humanitarian consequences of sending so many bombs, or so many aircraft, to a particular ally or partner. It was a good place to see exactly what alliance required.

;

;Paul joined PM, he told me, because he thought the United States was, relative to its competitors, a positive force in the world, and that arms transfers could be a way to save civilian lives and protect democracies. (Israel's Iron Dome anti-missile system, Paul said, is an example of the good version of such military aid, since it is used to protect the lives of Israeli civilians.) He also came to believe that he could exercise some moral influence over the use of such weaponry. The longest debate of Paul's tenure at PM was over the decision (made first by the Obama Administration, and extended under President Trump) to arm Saudi Arabia during its campaign against pro-Iranian Houthi militias in Yemen. For nearly a decade, the State Department's attention to the consequences of this decision were, Paul said, “microscopic.” Charts would be made estimating the number of civilian casualties each month and then there would be lengthy debates—were the Saudis killing more innocent Yemenis, or fewer? The US government sent a senior adviser, ;Larry Lewis;, out into the field to help the Saudis with their targeting and with the rules of engagement. “There was a long debate about how far into Saudi and Saudi-coalition military processes can we get without actually implicating ourselves,” Paul told me. He had been part of an internal push to get the US to further restrain the Saudi military, and felt that these efforts had helped preserve the lives of Yemeni civilians. But, when I asked Paul whether he felt that the US had got the balance of interests and humanitarian aims more or less right in Yemen, he said, “No, we got it very wrong.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;During the two years before Hamas's act of mass murder, the world of arms transfers had been preoccupied with ;weapons for Ukraine;. One of the most divisive issues at the State Department was whether the US should supply Kyiv with cluster munitions, which, because of the high rate of civilian casualties associated with them, have been banned by a number of US allies. In the end, Paul supported sending them, a decision that the Biden Administration eventually arrived at, too. Paul said, “Having made all these arms transfers and having made the ultimate decision that 'Hey, these aren't always bad,' one of the differences I have with the left is that the perfect should not be the enemy of the good.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;
;
;

;Paul was overseas on personal leave in the immediate aftermath of October 7th, but it was obvious to him that the US would be transferring arms to Israel after the attack. Many of those transfers, Paul knew, would happen almost instantly. For decades, the United States has maintained a vast weapons stockpile in Israel, which the IDF can draw from if Washington authorizes it. (In the first days after Hamas's attack, that authorization process was already under way.)

;

;Paul noticed some aspects of the diplomatic situation that should have raised alarms back in PM, among them the suggestion by Israeli leaders that Palestinian civilians were implicated in the Hamas attacks. On October 13th, Israel's President, Isaac Herzog, said, “It's an entire nation out there that is responsible. It's not true—this rhetoric about civilians not aware, not involved—it's absolutely not true.” Israel is a technologically advanced country with a well-resourced military; it has, as Paul put it, “a lot of bombs.” But the difference made by American support, he went on, was the difference between a vast but limited lethal capacity and a functionally unlimited one. “There would come a point without American support where Israel would have to say, 'Well, we need to be more selective.' If they are resource-unlimited, then they might say, 'Well, we might miss the Hamas guy here, and there might be twenty dead civilians. But it's worth a shot anyway, in case he's there, because there are enough bombs to do it.' ”

;

;Before he even got back to Washington, Paul began to draft his letter of resignation. But he also thought there was a chance that, beneath Biden's promises of military aid, some bureaucratic checks—against human-rights violations and against the killing of civilians—were under way. “A very simple thing that would have made a difference for me is, you know, knowing that there are units in the Israeli security forces that are of concern because of their track record of extrajudicial killings, seeing that some effort was being made not to give them more weapons,” Paul said. “That was not the case. In fact, where there had been debate, there was now no longer debate. It was, 'Let's give them weapons. It doesn't matter.' ” Both he and the State Department's Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor raised concerns about the lack of review of these arms transfers to certain Israeli units, Paul said. What they wanted, he went on, was to see “some space for, 'OK, we still have these values. We still have these concerns, they haven't gone away.' But there was none of that. It was, 'Open doors. Go.' ”

;

;Paul had spent the four years of the Trump Administration with a letter of resignation pre-written and tucked inside his desk, prepared for the worst. He never saw enough reason to submit it. When Biden was elected, he had been relieved: Biden's foreign-policy advisers emphasized human rights, and his campaign proposals included some initiatives, among them further restrictions on the overseas transfers of guns, that Paul believed in. Many of Biden's senior aides, from the national-security adviser ;Jake Sullivan; on down, were only a bit older than us, and their formative experiences were also of the post-9/11 war on terror and its excesses and errors. But Paul thought that he and they had taken slightly different lessons from watching the same bad wars. “It's interesting,” he said. “There's not a lot of people on the civilian side of government in this Administration who were in Iraq and Afghanistan, because it's a Democratic Administration and those were Bush wars.”

;

;The war in Israel and Gaza is now, in part, Biden's. A week after Paul and I had met in Washington, I wrote back to him to see what he made of it. Israel's promised ground invasion of Gaza had not yet begun in full, but the devastation was immeasurable, and, in a week when the grimmest news was an Israeli air strike on ;the Jabalia refugee camp;, many Palestinian civilians had already been killed. When he wrote back, he sounded both attuned to the bleakness of the situation in Israel and Gaza, and frustrated at how little the US seemed to be doing to alleviate it. “We wasted thirty years in which we could have remade the world,” Paul wrote. “Where once we were guided by hope we let ourselves be overtaken by fear. I think that's the legacy of the Great War on Terror—a nation whose greatest fear is not terrorism, per se, but rather that it may succumb to a destiny it did not choose.”

;
;
;

;Americans are fond of talking about the Israel-Palestine conflict as if it were stuck in a permanent historical loop, but maybe the US is stuck in a twentieth-century loop, too. “I feel increasingly like we are making the same mistakes,” Paul said. ♦
